I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Since 1999 the Government of Indonesia has introduced major decentralization reforms 
that  have  devolved  significant  authorities,  functional  responsibilities,  and  funding  from  the 
central government to provincial, district, and city governments. With the support of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB), with which it has been working since 1998, the Government has 
developed a medium-term sector development program, the National Action Plan for Fiscal 
Decentralization (NAPFD) 2005–2009. An ADB program loan of $300 million for the First Local 
Government  Finance  and  Governance  Reform  Program  (LGFGRP  1)  was  approved  and 
disbursed in a single tranche in 2005. A related project loan of $30 million, mainly to support 
investments  in  subnational  governments,  was  approved  in  late  2005  and  is  now  being 
implemented. Since the start of LGFGRP 1 processing around 2003, the Government has made 
very significant progress including: (i) putting in place a comprehensive package of financial 
laws and regulations reaching down to the districts and cities ; (ii) improving coordination across 
central and regional governments, partly by strengthening the President’s main decentralization 
advisory  body  (Dewan  Pertimbangan  Otonomi  Daerah  [DPOD]);  (iii) introducing  technical 
improvements  in  grant  transfer  formulation,  thus  improving  horizontal  and  vertical  equity; 
(iv) preparing a sectorwide medium-term plan (NAPFD) to strengthen financial management 
aspects of decentralization; (v) drafting a taxation reform bill, now before the national parliament 
(Dewan Perwakilan Rakyat [DPR]) to strengthen the local tax base while lessening the impact of 
small nuisance taxes; and (vi) making significant longer-term efforts to strengthen financial 
systems, institutions, and human capacity at decentralized levels, with major financial and 
technical support from ADB and other donors.1   
 
2  During  the  2006  Country  Programming  Mission,  the  Government  reaffirmed  the 
understanding it had reached with ADB in 2005 under LGFGRP 1 to proceed to a second 
program loan, and requested ADB for technical assistance2 (TA) to support (i) a review of policy 
progress and updating of the NAPFD, (ii) the preparation of an agreed set of policy actions for 
implementation under LGFGRP 2, and (iii) completion of the finally agreed actions. The current 
country strategy and program, (CSP) 2006–2009,3 puts decentralization and local government 
finance and governance issues at the forefront. The project preparatory TA (PPTA) and the 
proposed LGFGRP 2 are part of the CSP and received concept clearance at the TA Concept 
Paper Meeting in April 2007. The Government has confirmed the impact, outcome, outputs, and 
implementation arrangements (Appendix 1); cost and financing arrangements (Appendix 2); and 
terms of reference for the PPTA (Appendix 3).  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  In many respects the very significant (“big bang”) approach to decentralization begun in 
2001 in Indonesia has been a qualified success. Reforms have involved the massive delegation

of  responsibility  for  public  service  provision  and  the  reassignment  of  two  thirds  of  central 
government civil servants and more than 16,000 service delivery facilities to the subnational 
governments. The share of regional governments in total government expenditures has nearly 
doubled, to almost 40%, making Indonesia one of Asia’s most decentralized countries. Fears 
about the potential chaos that could follow the “big bang” have not materialized. However, over 
the last 6 years there has been continuous need for reform and fine-tuning, to make the 
decentralized system more functional and coherent. In particular, issues of quality and equity of 
service delivery between poor and better-off regions require long-term attention, as do issues 
like transparency, accountability, and capacity.  
 
4.  The  first  program  loan  focused  on  supporting  the  Government  in  finalizing  a  large 
number of legal, regulatory, and policy reforms to underpin the major political moves toward 
decentralization  from  1999.  As  part  of  this  support,  the  NAPFD  was  prepared  by  the 
Government to guide further planning and policy work in 2005–2009. The NAPFD provides a 
very extensive menu of further reforms and capacity development initiatives for the medium to 
longer term. A wide range of NAPFD-planned future actions were considered in designing the 
technical assistance. In addition, a joint study by the Government and ADB in March 2007 
identified a subset of the priority areas to be included in the PPTA.  
 
5.  The study identified broad issues for more detailed review and possible inclusion under 
the PPTA and eventually LGFGRP 2. The issues were: (i) the rapid creation of new regional 
governments; 4 (ii) the unclear assignment of expenditure responsibilities; (iii) the contradictory 
functional assignments in the decentralization laws vis-à-vis the sectoral laws, along with the 
encroachment of central government agencies on the functional responsibilities of regional 
governments; (iv) uncertainty about the quality of service delivered by regional governments; 
(v) the  inefficient  composition  of  regional  government  expenditures, with  a  disproportionate 
share  of  wages  and  salaries  and  general  administration  services;  (vi) the  insufficient 
decentralization of revenues, with own revenues making up a small share of regional revenues, 
complicated  by  distortional  nuisance  local  taxes;  (vii)  the  large  system  of  unconditional 
equalization  grants  (dana  alokasi  umum  [DAU])  with  a  diminished  equalization  impact  on 
horizontal fiscal disparities because of a hold-harmless provision for all regional governments 
and DAU fund diversion to pay all civil servants of regional governments directly from the center; 
(viii) the incipient but fast-growing system of conditional and special grants (dana alokasi khusus 
[DAK]), which are still improperly defined and underfunded, although there are plans to shift 
“deconcentrated funds,” now administered by the line ministries and central agencies, to the 
DAK; (ix) the low levels of borrowing by regional governments; and (x) the lack of capacity and 
human  capital  for  proper  planning,  budgeting,  and  execution  despite  the  adequate  legal 
framework for budgeting, and the overall weakness in external audit and evaluation.  
 
6.  The review confirmed the importance of these issues and discussions during fact finding 
mission brought out the fact that some (notably issues v, vii, viii, and x) are being addressed by 
the Government in varying degrees. The PPTA will address the core issues among those 
remaining (notably i, ii, iii, vi, and viii), and may also deal with other issues if necessary. As 
requested by the Government, the country’s recent experiences with policy reform, particularly 
under LGFGRP 1, will be evaluated and the NAPFD policy matrix will be updated to guide the 
development of proposed actions under LGFGRP 2 and the work of the PPTA. The formal 
review may largely confirm the findings of the background study even as it provides opportunity 
for flexibility in the PPTA activities.

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The  anticipated  impact  of  the  longer-term  program  is  more  transparent,  efficient, 
equitable, and effective management and use of public resources for regional development 
through better intergovernmental financing arrangements, including fiscal transfers and local 
taxes. The expected outcome of the PPTA will be the adoption of policy changes by the 
Government  in  local  government  finance  and  governance  reforms  leading  to  the  timely 
processing of LGFGRP 2. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
8.  From  the  NAPFD  and  the  diagnostic  paper,  substantive  policy  actions  that  the 
Government can implement with the support of the PPTA, have been identified. Whereas the 
key PPTA activities correspond closely to the anticipated policy matrix under the proposed 
program  loan,  the  policy  matrix  requires  considerable  further  discussion  between  the 
Government and ADB. The PPTA activities (and thus the PPTA approach) must therefore 
remain flexible. In addition to the activities listed below, the eventual program loan policy matrix 
will record the many other achievements that have been made or are being undertaken through 
the Government’s own efforts since 2005. The proposed PPTA activities are as follows. 
 
9.  Activity 1: Take stock of LGFGRP performance and update the NAPFD policy 
matrix. At the start of the PPTA, the performance under LGFGRP 1 will be evaluated and the 
NAPFD policy matrix will be updated, leading to the preparation of a government policy paper 
setting out revisions in the NAPFD policy matrix and recommendations for an appropriate policy 
action matrix for the LGFGRP 2. As mentioned in paras 4 and 5 above, a broad study was done 
to  identify  areas  where  reform  interventions  would  be  more  rewarding.  However,  the 
Government is interested in a joint formal review that may shape the ultimate scope of the 
PPTA.  The  stocktaking  will  allow  the  proposed  PPTA  activities  to  be  fine-tuned  and  may 
indicate additional activities that need to be undertaken. Badan Perencanaan Pembangunan 
Nasional (BAPPENAS), the national development planning agency, will be the Implementing 
Agency (IA) for this activity in close coordination with the Ministry of Finance (MOF) and the 
Ministry of Home Affairs (MOHA). 
 
10.  Activity 2: Support the Government and ADB in preparing a final policy action 
matrix. The matrix will benefit from the joint study, the updated NAPFD policy matrix prepared 
under activity 1, and the background studies to be done for activities 1–6. The Directorate 
General of Fiscal Balance of the MOF will be the IA for this activity. 
 
11.   Activity 3: In support of two new forthcoming government regulations, study and 
draft  a  grand  strategy  paper  for  the  national  parliament  (DPR)  addressing  the 
proliferation of new subnational governments. The PPTA will support a further study of the 
costs and benefits of creating regional governments and the implications for service delivery. It 
will assist MOHA in analyzing the evaluation data it is now collecting on the size, economic 
bases, amalgamation policy options, performance, and other aspects of the operations of new 
regional governments. This analysis and other information to be collected will assist MOHA in 
drafting for the DPR a grand strategy paper on the optimal number of regional governments in 
Indonesia. This strategy paper will support the implementation of two forthcoming government 
regulations on the evaluation of (i) proposals for the establishment of new regional governments, 
and (ii) the performance of regional governments (including their dissolution or merger). The IA

4   
for this activity will be the Directorate of Regional Management and Special Autonomy, under 
the Directorate General of Regional Autonomy of MOHA. 
 
12.  Activity 4: Support the amendment of sector laws and regulations to make them 
consistent  with  the  new  expenditure  assignments  and  other  legislation  on 
decentralization. The PPTA will support the removal of inefficiencies and confusion caused by 
inconsistent  legislation  dating  back  to  pre-decentralization  times.  It  will  also  support  the 
preparation of mapping documentation to identify amendments to the main set of sectoral laws 
and regulations required by the new Regulation 38/07 on Assignment of Expenditures. Policy 
and practical recommendations will be made regarding the best approaches to dealing with the 
massive regulatory load (at least 31 laws and 600 regulations to be reviewed, according to initial 
assessments). Additionally, detailed recommendations and draft amendments to relevant laws 
and regulations will be prepared for two pilot ministries to be selected at the start. Overview 
information will be provided to allow monitoring of the national response while reform strategies 
are being developed for the ministries and particularly for the two pilot ministries. The IA for this 
activity will be the Directorate of Regional Autonomy Facilitation under the Directorate General 
of Regional Autonomy of MOHA.  
 
13.  Activity  5:  Study  options  for  enhancing  the  revenue  autonomy  of  regional 
governments, particularly by decentralizing the property tax. The PPTA will support the 
IA—the Directorate of Regional Taxes and Redistribution under the Directorate General of 
Fiscal Balance of the MOF—in studying the options for the phased decentralization of the 
property tax, including such matters as the rate-setting discretion of regional governments; the 
sectors to be decentralized (only urban and rural properties or also the forestry, mining, and 
oil/petroleum sectors); and the feasibility of asymmetric administration of large cities. The study 
must build flexibly on amendments to Law 34/00 on Regional Taxes and Redistribution, now 
under debate in the DPR and likely to be passed by early 2008. The Government and DPR are 
expected to take a phased approach to the decentralization of the property tax. The PPTA will 
support further phases of regulatory and legal reforms as well as practical planning of the 
implementation of the first phase of reforms, and also the development of a medium-term road 
map for tax and revenue reforms (as a subset of the NAPFD). But the LGFGR 2 program loan 
actions are not likely to extend to the passage of amendments by the Government and DPR 
other than those now before them, as these amendments can take considerable time. 
 
14.  Activity 6: Carry out policy work to support the transfer of deconcentration funds 
to the DAK. Depending on the progress in the implementation of Law 33/04 on DAK and 
subject to further discussions with the Government, this activity may be partially or completely 
revised during TA start-up. The PPTA will support the IA—the Directorate of Evaluation of 
Regional Financial Information under the Directorate General of Fiscal Balance of the MOF—in 
planning the transition of deconcentration funds, where appropriate, for switching to the DAK 
within  a  clear  time  frame.  Significant  deconcentration  funds  (at  least  50%  of  appropriate 
programs and activities, compared with the actual 2007 outcomes) are likely to be transferred to 
the DAK in the 2009 budget submission. The PPTA will support MOF in identifying key areas of 
deconcentration funding and in developing strategies for making budget changes in at least two 
key sector ministries.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The total cost of the PPTA is estimated at $1 million equivalent. The PPTA in the amount 
of $700,000 will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded by the 
Government of Japan. The ADB financing will cover consulting services, report production, and

5
miscellaneous administrative and workshop costs. The Government will finance the remaining 
$300,000 equivalent to cover mainly in-kind office accommodation and support services (see 
Appendix 2). The Government has been informed that approval of the PPTA does not commit 
ADB to financing any ensuing program or project, nor the Government to borrowing the funds. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  As agreed, the Executing Agency for the PPTA will be the MOF Directorate General of 
Fiscal Balance, most likely through the Office of the Secretary to the Director General. MOF, 
MOHA,  and  BAPPENAS  will  be  the  Implementing  Agencies  for  the  different  activities,  as 
detailed above. A small high-level external advisory panel, to be composed of Indonesian 
academics and representatives from regional governments, will be appointed to provide peer 
review and quality oversight, to coordinate between key government agencies and the PPTA 
team, and to provide a regional government perspective. 
 
17.  International consultants will be hired for 14 person-months and national consultants for 
33  person-months,  to  provide  expertise  in  fiscal  policy  aspects  of  decentralization, 
intergovernmental  financial  arrangements,  optimal  sizes  of  regional  governments,  property 
taxation, structuring of specific grants, deconcentration funding, and preparation of amendments 
to financial laws and regulations. The outline terms of reference and reporting arrangements are 
set out in Appendix 3. All the consultants will be hired as individuals by ADB according to its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Experience in 
Indonesia has shown that hiring consulting firms is much more expensive than hiring individual 
consultants, and does not always produce the right mix of consultants. The hiring of individual 
consultants is also justified for the following reasons: (i) a single firm will be hard put to provide 
the diverse set of specialized skills required; (ii) while timing is of the essence in ensuring that 
the PPTA outputs make a meaningful contribution to the preparation of the LGFGRP 2 starting 
in November 2007, firm recruitment adds 4 months to the start-up; and (iii) any difficulties in 
project administration will be mitigated by engaging a national project administrator and an 
international team leader, who will help coordinate and manage the recruitment process. 
 
18.  The PPTA is expected to be implemented over a 12-month period, starting in January 
2008. The outputs—in the form of policy reports and policy-related seminars and workshops—
will be disseminated progressively after the negotiations for the proposed LGFGRP 2 program 
loan. An updated NAPFD policy matrix will be published and widely distributed. The proposed 
external advisory panel will assist ADB in providing quality control and outcome evaluation. 
MOF has agreed to facilitate the provision of adequate furnished office accommodation for the 
PPTA  team,  including  telephone  and  fax  lines  and  Internet  connection  facilities.  Both 
BAPPENAS and MOHA will also provide adequate desk space for the consultants who will work 
from there intermittently. Basic office and computer equipment worth $12,000 will be purchased 
for the team. These assets will be procured and disposed by the consultants in accordance with 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2007 as amended from time to time).     
     
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $700,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  Indonesia  for  preparing  the  Second  Local  Government  Finance  and 
Governance Reform Program, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  These outline terms of reference allow flexibility in aligning the consultants’ tasks with 
the Government’s emerging needs for required and agreed policy actions for the proposed 
program loan for the Second Local Government Finance and Governance Reform Program 
(LGFGRP 2). As the project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) is focused on supporting 
the preparation and completion of required policy actions for the LGFGRP 2 program loan, the 
PPTA experts will need to provide inputs and expertise flexibly in the design and implementation 
of program actions. 
 
2.  The PPTA will require a combination of international and national experts who are 
experienced with the Indonesian decentralization approaches and framework and who have the 
skills  required  for  particular  positions  in  program  loan  preparation,  fiscal  policy  aspects  of

I.  POVERTY ISSUES 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
The Government’s Medium-Term Development Plan 2005–2009 seeks to raise the levels of sustainable economic 
growth, create jobs, and accelerate the achievement of the MDGs. The strategic goal of decentralization is greater 
fiscal and human capacity for sustainable service delivery. The Government has identified a few key constraints that 
need to be addressed: (i) unequal financing of the regions, (ii) lack of capacity at the local level, and (iii) fragility of 
districts throughout the country. 
 
ADB’s strategy for 2006–2009 is to help the Government achieve higher levels of pro-poor sustainable growth and to 
enhance social development. One of the five key areas of ADB’s engagement is improving decentralization, with 
enhanced financial reporting as a key indicator. ADB’s support for decentralization is aimed at the following outcomes: 
(i) sustainable financing of local government investments, (ii) improved capacity for fiscal accountability at the local 
levels,  (iii)  clearer  intergovernmental  fiscal  relations,  (iv)  well-defined  functional  assignments  at  all  levels  of 
government, (v) central government financing for local government based on needs, (vi) establishment of clear local 
government fiscal accountability framework, and (vii) strengthened regional government capacity. 
 
B.     Targeting Classification          
1.  Select the targeting classification of the project: 
 
 General Intervention    Individual or Household (TI-H);  Geographic (TI-G);  Non-Income MDGs (TI-M1, M2, 
etc.) 
 
2.   Explain the basis for the targeting classification:  
 
Poverty reduction will be addressed indirectly through support for improved policies and arrangements for fiscal 
transfers from the central Government to local governments, and improved tax regimes for local governments. The 
improved fiscal transfer policies will reduce fiscal inequality across regions, providing poorer regions with additional 
resources. The improved tax regimes will enhance the ability of local governments to generate their own revenues 
through property taxes and local business taxes. The improved local allocations can be spent on development to spur 
local growth—the most effective channel for poverty reduction. 
 
C.  Poverty Analysis 
1.  If the project is classified as TI-H, or if it is policy-based, what type of poverty impact analysis is needed?  
 
The various policy reform measures proposed will have to be examined for possible poverty and social impact. 
 
2.  What resources are allocated in the PPTA/due diligence?  
 
Coordination of poverty and social analysis work is been included in the TOR of the team leader and the national fiscal 
decentralization policy expert to ensure that the poverty/social impact of the policy measures proposed by the various 
experts is taken into account. 
 
3.  If GI, is there any opportunity for pro-poor design (e.g., social inclusion subcomponents, cross subsidy, pro-poor 
governance, and pro-poor growth)? 
 
LGFGRP 2 is designed to improve pro-poor governance, as explained under B.2.

II.  SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT ISSUES 
A.  Initial Social Analysis 
Based on existing information: 
 
1.  Who are the potential primary beneficiaries of the project? How do the poor and the socially excluded benefit 
from the project? 
 
The local governments will be the primary beneficiaries of the improved fiscal arrangements. The poor and socially 
excluded will benefit indirectly when the available public resources are used for local development. 
 
2.  What are the potential needs of beneficiaries in relation to the proposed project? 
 
Their potential needs are socialization of policy reforms, and capacity building in financial management and local 
budget preparation. 
 
3.  What are the potential constraints in accessing the proposed benefits and services, and how will the project 
address them? 
 
The constraints will be identified during the review and updating of the NAPFD. The constraints will be addressed over 
time. LGFGRP 2 needs to be seen as one step in the process of identifying the constraints. The program loan will 
address some of the constraints. Over time, other constraints will be addressed by subsequent interventions. 
 
B.  Consultation and Participation 
1. Indicate the potential initial stakeholders. 
 
The initial stakeholders are the technical staff of the Directorate General of Fiscal Balance of the Ministry of Finance, 
the Directorate General of Regional Autonomy (OTDA) of the Ministry of Home Affairs, and the Decentralization 
Directorate of BAPPENAS (national  development planning agency), who  will  benefit from the technical inputs 
provided. 
 
2. What type of consultation and participation (C&P) is required during the PPTA or project processing (e.g., 
workshops,  community  mobilization,  involvement  of  non  government  organizations  and  community-based 
organizations, etc.)? 
 
There will be day-to-day interaction between the technical staff in the involved ministries and the consultants. 
Occasionally, workshops based on the needs expressed will be organized. The PPTA is also allocating a budget for a 
senior external advisory panel, composed of senior national experts outside government, to discuss and comment on 
the various reform options. 
 
3.  What level of participation is envisaged for project design? 
  
    Information sharing          Consultation         Collaborative decision making         Empowerment 
4.  Will a C&P plan be prepared?    Yes          No    Please explain.  
 
Given the limited number of initial stakeholders and the technical nature of the work, C&P will be organized as 
explained under B.2. 
 
C.  Gender and Development 
 
1.  What are the key gender issues in the sector/subsector that are likely to be relevant to this project/program? 
 
Decentralization that cuts across sectors can have indirect gender impact through the promotion of participatory 
policy-making processes in local governments that enable women to have a much greater say in decisions that affect 
their lives. LGFGRP 2 is not, however, expected to have any significant direct gender impact, as it stops short of 
participatory policy-making processes and is focused on the improvement of fiscal policies and allocations.
